supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for initial operations, strained for sustained offensive. Operation Torch provided 30-day stockpiles at landing sites. Primary constraints: limited port capacity at Oran and Algiers (10,000 tons/day combined), long supply lines to Tunisia front (400-800km), inadequate forward depots, inexperienced logistics staff, and competing demands from British First Army. Fuel prioritized for armored operations, ammunition adequate for defensive operations but constrained for sustained offensive. Desert operations revealed American logistical inexperience with water supply, vehicle maintenance, and forward supply dumps.

tactical_doctrine.role: First major US ground combat corps in European Theater. Operation Torch marked the American Army's entry into sustained combat against Axis forces. II Corps conducted amphibious landings at multiple points across French North Africa (8 November 1942), overcame limited Vichy French resistance, then transitioned to offensive operations into Tunisia against German and Italian forces. Doctrine emphasized firepower, mobility, and aggressive offensive action, though inexperience led to costly lessons at engagements like Medjez el Bab and (later) Kasserine Pass.

known_issues: Green troops - first combat for all units
37mm AT guns inadequate against German armor (discovered in Tunisia)
Dispersal of units by higher command reduced corps cohesion
Coordination challenges between American and British forces
Intelligence failures regarding German strength and capability in Tunisia
Tank design deficiencies (M3 Lee tall profile, riveted armor)
Training gaps in mine warfare, desert navigation, and combined arms
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Minimal as of Q4 1942. Operation Torch was coastal assault, not desert operation. Tunisia fighting (starting December 1942) revealed critical gaps in desert warfare knowledge: water discipline, vehicle sand filters, maintenance in austere conditions, navigation without landmarks, and effects of heat/cold on equipment. Rapid learning curve but at cost of casualties and equipment losses.
